required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Are NSAIDs Effective Enough for Postoperative Pain Control After Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery and Septoplasty
clinical_study.official_title: Are NSAIDs Effective Enough for Postoperative Pain Control After Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery and Septoplasty

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare the level of pain control in patients receiving non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to those receiving opioids in the postoperative period after endoscopic sinus surgery (ESS) and/or septoplasty.

primary_outcome.measure: Pain Score as Assessed by a 100mm Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)
primary_outcome.description: The range of scores on the VAS is 0 to 100, with 100 being the highest level of pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Score as Assessed by a 100mm Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)
secondary_outcome.description: The range of scores on the VAS is 0 to 100, with 100 being the highest level of pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Score as Assessed by a 100mm Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)
secondary_outcome.description: The range of scores on the VAS is 0 to 100, with 100 being the highest level of pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Pain Score as Assessed by a 100mm Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)
secondary_outcome.description: The range of scores on the VAS is 0 to 100, with 100 being the highest level of pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Bleeding Complications
secondary_outcome.description: Bleeding complications are defined as complications necessitating a trip to the emergency room or requiring intervention for epistaxis.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Nausea or Vomiting

clinical_study.condition: Pain Control After Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery and Septoplasty

arm_group.description: The non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used in this study is diclofenac.
The Opioid used in this study is Norco. Norco is a combination medication that contains both an opioid pain reliever (hydrocodone) and a non-opioid pain reliever (acetaminophen).

intervention.description: The non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used in this study is diclofenac.
The opioid used in this study is Norco. Norco is a combination medication that contains both an opioid pain reliever (hydrocodone) and a non-opioid pain reliever (acetaminophen).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- english speaking
- candidates for endoscopic sinus surgery as determined by medical necessity by the treating rhinologist
- scheduled for surgery at Texas Sinus Institute
Exclusion Criteria:
- allergy to either NSAIDs or opioids
- contraindication to NSAIDs (ex. gastritis, chronic kidney disease)
- surgical plan exceeding basic endoscopic sinus surgery
- use of anticoagulation
- the presence of any pain disorder
- the current usage of any analgesic medication
- history of opioid addiction
- pregnancy
- history of chronic pain or fibromyalgia
- current daily use of NSAIDs, acetaminophen, opioids or other analgesics (pregabalin, tramadol, etc)

outcome.title: Pain Score as Assessed by a 100mm Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)
outcome.description: The range of scores on the VAS is 0 to 100, with 100 being the highest level of pain.
outcome.population: Data was not collected for 26 in the NSAID arm and 17 in the opioid arm.
